Award.AwardTitle: Sobolev Mappings and Energy-Integrals in Mathematical Models of Nonlinear Elasticity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal continues a long term research program of the PI to advance variational techniques in Geometric Function Theory with applied disciplines in mind. It provides an in-depth analysis of the concept of energy-minimal deformations between Euclidean domains (predominantly, traction free problems in dimension two). The ambition is to gain insights into the many new phenomena encountered in the Calculus of Variations, Minimal Surfaces, Nonlinear Elasticity, Material Science, and so forth. Historical example would be the celebrated mathematical structure -Teichm√ºller spaces, where one seeks to minimize the supremum norm of the distortion function. Other examples could be cited. We shall minimize the integral mean distortion instead. The existence and uniqueness of the mappings slipping along the boundary (traction free) with smallest mean distortion takes the challenge to a whole new level.
The project continues the efforts of the PI to bring graduate students and postdoctoral scholars to Geometric Analysis with a wide range of applications, and to help them to mature meaningful interaction with physicists and engineers already in their post-doc phase. This is also a key to motivate young gifted students at school or college to enter mathematics. The program provides such an environment through educational materials (book in progress), Summer/Winter mini-courses, junior-senior seminars. PI has a history of an engaging research climate and strong international interaction on these efforts. He anticipates that the presence of applied fields in the proposal will improve the job opportunities for the PhD students and his numerous co-advisees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The major part of this project reflects a long term research program of the PI to advance variational techniques in Geometric Function Theory (GFT) and the associated nonlinear partial differential equations (PDEs). Over the last decades there has been an intense exploration of the ideas of GFT, leading to challenging problems and new research areas. Applications are plentiful and quite significant. Deformations of material bodies, crystals, etc. have fascinated generations of famous mathematicians for centuries: G. Galileo. H. Hook, L. Euler, J-L. Lagrange. T. Young. A. Cauchy, G. Green, G.R. Kirchoff. At the present stage, mathematical models of Nonlinear Elasticity (NE) is an active science and its future development and strategy predict well new mathematical areas to study. The project provides an in-depth analysis of mathematical models of NE with the intention to make it precise and a reliable theory. For example, the Principle of Non-Interpenetration of Matter demands to include the monotone and cellular Sobolev mappings as legitimate deformations of elastic bodies.  In fact monotone Sobolev mappings (substitutes of homeomorphisms) are at the heart of this proposal. Topological arguments for nonlinear PDEs and Calculus of Variations (CV) become quintessential as never before. Conversely, the modern variational approach to GFT and NE turned out to be profoundly insightful for solving long standing mathematical problems; such as the 50 years old Nitsche Conjecture,  the Ball-Evans Conjecture or the new concept of so-called free Lagrangians for establishing the existence of energy-minimal deformations.

Broader Impact: This program seeks to do much more than to obtain new results in GFT or NE. The aim is to encourage students to participate in the interdisciplinary efforts. For example, theoretical prediction of failure of material bodies (propagation of cracks along trajectories of Hopf differential, recent results of the PI and J. Onninen) should appeal to both mathematical analysts and researchers in the engineering fields. These efforts have been particularly effective through international meetings with active groups of applied mathematicians. Lectures accessible for nonspecialized audiences are the key to attract students and young gifted scholars to join such efforts. Just to mention Vigure Lectures at Louisiana State University (Fall 2013), Lectures at the new Centre of Doctoral Training of the University of Oxford, April 17-May22, 2015. International summer school in Barcelona, 2018.  The PI was awarded NSF funds to support US graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to participate in the international conference in Bedlewo (Poland, August 2016). Its special location attracted young gifted scholars, women and men, from Central and Eastern Europe who did not have the means to visit the USA. Over the last 5 years the PI provided an active research habitat for both Syracuse University students and some from other universities, in the USA (Vigre Lectures at Louisiana State University in Fall 2013 ) or overseas (lectures at the new Centre of Doctoral Training of the University of Oxford, April 17-May 22, 2015, and  Summer School in Barcelona in 2018). Dissemination of research to broader scientific community has been accomplished through educational materials. Jani Onninen and the PI continue working on a monograph “Variational Integrals in Geometric Function Theory”.

 


Last Modified: 09/10/2018
Modified by: Tadeusz Iwaniec
